Tips

There are certain tips that can be useful for beginning to write mathematical arguments.

  1. State what you are trying to prove. This means you will always have a clear idea of the destination you are trying to reach with your arguments.
  2. Plan the structure of your proof. This should help to avoid the problem discussed above, of statements not following from each other. It is often useful to have such a 'plan of attack'.
  3. Do not expect to write a complete proof first time. More often we need a lot of rough working before we formalise our arguments in order to write a neat, full proof.
  4. Mathematics is written in full sentences using good english. Mathematical symbols often mean nothing unless we have a sentence explaining them. For example consider the difference between a statement being true for only even numbers vs being true for only odd numbers. Therefore a calculation without context does not constitute a full proof.
  5. Present calculations in a manner that is easy to follow. Include enough detail to make a proof easy to check. This often depends on the experience of the writer and reader. Often in textbooks smaller steps may be missed in a proof because they are clear to the author, or are expected to be clear to the reader. When writing your own proofs, if a logical step is not clear to you then this isn't a full proof. Think about writing your argument so that you can explain it fully.
  6. It is often helpful to use diagrams or examples to illustrate different concepts within your arguments.

There are a lot of different styles of proof. No one style is intrinsically better than another - it is often a case of personal preference. However, always remember that a mathematical proof is an argument designed to convince the reader that a statement is true. So it must be written in enough detail to effectively do this.
